Award.AwardTitle: Project Intro Astro: Transforming Undergraduate Education in Introductory Astronomy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-CH) has built PROMPT, which consists of six 16-inch diameter fully automated, or robotic, telescopes at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile, and Skynet -- telescope control and web-based, dynamic queue scheduling software. In partnership with other institutions, Skynet has enabled PROMPT to grow into a network of 16 small, robotic optical telescopes currently spanning South America, North America, and Europe. Over the past three years, the PI and members of the Skynet team have been spearheading an expansion and modernization of UNC-CH's introductory astronomy curriculum, capitalizing on new facilities, and on Skynet and PROMPT in particular. This project expands the effort into a joint program between UNC-CH and Wake Technical Community College (WTCC).

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The goals of the UNC-CH-WTCC partnership are three-fold: (1) To modernize those components of WTCC's introductory astronomy curriculum that UNC-CH has already transformed, specifically its first introductory astronomy laboratory course, ASTR 101L, and a unique fieldwork experience called Education Research in Radio Astronomy (ERIRA), and to provide WTCC's astronomy faculty with the training and the tools to teach ASTR 101L; (2) To work together to complete the transformation of UNC- CH's first introductory lecture course, ASTR 101, to a "flipped," active-learning experience, to work together to develop a second introductory astronomy laboratory course, ASTR 102L, and to implement these courses at both institutions; and (3) To assess the effectiveness of the new curriculum along three axes: (1) traditional lectures/labs vs. flipped lectures/Skynet-based labs, (2) research university vs. community college, and (3) on campus vs. online.

The project is partnering with the professional evaluators at UNC-CH's Center for Faculty Excellence and WTCC's Institutional Research and Planning office to evaluate the new curriculum. They are measuring improvement in student learning and engagement. Additionally, the project is tracking the number of students who progress from ASTR 101 to ASTR 102, from there to ERIRA or ASTR102L, and at UNC-CH from there to a major or minor in astrophysics.

BROADER IMPACTS: The PI is uploading his ASTR 101 lectures to a YouTube channel called Project Intro Astro. The current project is also developing a website that fully describes and facilitates Project Intro Astro, the goal of which is for anyone to be able to take any of four introductory astronomy courses, including two Skynet-based laboratory courses, either (1) self-paced for free (i.e., the MIT model), or for the cost of their text, or (2) for credit/transfer credit though UNC- CH's Friday Center for Continuing Education's Carolina Courses Online (including WTCC students). The expanded website is also a repository for the active learning materials that are being developed (including access to a novel, and expanded, e-polling interface), for other educators who might want to adopt the videos and materials to flip their own classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-CH) began building “Skynet” and “PROMPT” in 2004.  Skynet is sophisticated telescope control and queue scheduling software.  Skynet enables telescopes to function either individually or as an integrated whole, even if at multiple sites, all controlled through a single, web-based user interface.  Skynet is capable of controlling scores of telescopes simultaneously, including most commercially available small-telescope hardware.  The Skynet Robotic Telescope Network now spans four continents and five countries.

PROMPT is a subset of the Skynet Robotic Telescope Network, consisting of our highest-quality telescopes at our highest-quality sites.  Currently, PROMPT consists of:  (1) three 16-inch, three 24-inch, and one 32-inch diameter telescopes at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO); and (2) four 17-inch diameter telescopes at Siding Spring Observatory (SSO) in eastern Australia.

Prior to this award, PI Reichart and members of the Skynet team had been spearheading an expansion and modernization of UNC-CH’s introductory astronomy curriculum, capitalizing on our new facilities, and on Skynet and PROMPT in particular.  This has resulted in a >100% in introductory astronomy enrollment (we are now serving approximately 1/5th of UNC-CH’s undergraduates) and an approximately 300% increase in astrophysics majors and minors.  With this award, we expanded this effort into a joint, and mutually beneficial, program between UNC-CH and Wake Technical Community College (WTCC).

The goals of the UNC-CH – WTCC partnership were three-fold:  (1) To immediately modernize those components of WTCC’s introductory astronomy curriculum that UNC-CH has already transformed, specifically its first introductory astronomy laboratory course, ASTR 101L, and a unique fieldwork experience called Education Research in Radio Astronomy (ERIRA), and to provide WTCC’s astronomy faculty with the training and the tools to carry out ASTR 101L successfully; and (2) To work together to complete the transformation of UNC-CH’s first introductory lecture course, ASTR 101, to a “flipped”, active-learning experience; and (3) To assess the effectiveness of the new curriculum.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:  A major component of this project has been the development and administration of instruments to collect data that we can then analyze to access the impact of the course components that we have been developing at UNC-CH and WTCC.  To this end, survey instruments were developed at UNC with assistance from personnel trained in surveys and course assessment from UNC’s Center for Faculty Excellence.  In particular, we developed two detailed surveys, one for students taking introductory astronomy courses, and one for the instructors of these courses.  These surveys were administered to students and instructors for a total of four semesters, and not only at UNC-CH and WTCC, but across ten participating institutions. 

A detailed analysis of these data, and report, was prepared by Dr. Adam Trotter.  Trotter's analysis focused not on learning gains, which have been well studied in introductory astronomy courses, but on attitudinal gains.  Given that introductory astronomy is the last science class that many students ever take, there is an argument to be made that this is actually more important, and where our focus should be. 

Many of Trotter's findings are obvious (e.g., students' attitude toward astronomy and STEM correlate with their expected grade).  However, by modeling many factors simultaneously, the obvious can be controlled for and more subtle factors can be unearthed.  We recommend reading Trotter's entire report, but the headline result is that of a great many course components tested, only two impacted students end-attitude about astronomy and STEM:  (1) the in-class lectures, as a function of how helpful they found them to be; and (2) our Skynet-based labs, again, as a function of how helpful they found them to be.  

 

BROADER IMPACTS:  Prior to this award, Reichart had been videoing his ASTR 101 lectures and has since been editing these videos into topical segments, and for audio, and uploading them to a YouTube channel that he created, called Project Intro Astro.  During this award, we developed a second website, linked to the YouTube site, that fully describes and facilitates Project Intro Astro, the goal of which is for anyone to be able to take any of our introductory astronomy courses, including our Skynet-based laboratory course, either (1) self-paced for free (i.e., the MIT model), or for the cost of their text, or (2) for credit/transfer credit though UNC-CH’s Friday Center for Continuing Education’s Carolina Courses Online (including WTCC students).  The expanded website will also be a repository for the active learning materials that we will develop (including access to a novel, and expanded, e-polling interface), for other educators who might want to adopt our videos and materials to “flip” their own classrooms.  These videos have now been viewed 143,046 times, for a total of 685,752 minutes = 11,429 hours = 379476 days = 1.30 years.  Average view duration is 4.78 minutes.
